source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Creep tests were carried out on specimens machined from heavily cold-worked Zircaloy-2 sheet material in both the rolling (longitudinal) and thickness (short-transverse) directions.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The texture of the sheet was such that the majority of grains had basal-plane normals oriented 30 deg from the sheet-normal direction, and was independent of the metallurgical condition.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The creep tests were carried out in the range 100 to 350 C on both as-received (cold-worked) and annealed material.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: At high stresses (all temperatures) such that rupture occurred in under 1000 h, the longitudinal specimens showed higher creep rates than the short-transverse specimens.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: However, at lower stresses the texture had very little effect on creep either in cold-worked material throughout the temperature range investigated, or in annealed materials between 250 and 310 C.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: In annealed materials tested at temperatures below 250 and above 310 C the longitudinal specimens had higher creep rates than the short-transverse ones.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The material exhibited strong dynamic strain aging which reached maximum intensity around 300 C.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: In some tests the creep came to a complete stop after about 1000 h.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Activation energy for creep determinations showed little variations with texture, but a very marked peaking in the strain-aging temperature range.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 Cold-rolled~ Batch A . . . 50% after annealing at 800 C

evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 Cold-rolled~ Batch B. . . 40% after annealing at 760 C

evidence_span: At temperatures below about half the melting point (below $6 5 0 \mathrm { { C } }$ for dilute zirconium alloys [13]) one would normally expect the value of the activation energy for creep to be below that for self-diffusion [14], that is, below 46,000 cal/mole [15].

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: The anomalously high values that were obtained with Zircaloy-2 between 250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$ during this investigation (Fig. 9) as well as by Holmes [16] are attributed to a solute-dislocation interaction.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk3
evidence_span: The anomalously high values that were obtained with Zircaloy-2 between 250 and $4 0 0 \mathrm { { C } }$ during this investigation (Fig. 9) as well as by Holmes [16] are attributed to a solute-dislocation interaction.

STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: A creep experiment on 23-mm diameter tubular specimens of Zircaloy-2 is described. The specimens are stressed biaxially at hoop stresses from 11 to 26 kgf/mm² at 260°C at three neutron flux conditions.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The results confirm that fast neutrons increase creep rates at all the stresses tested, but thermal neutrons have no detectable effect.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: A method is described for correlating biaxial tubular and uniaxial in-reactor creep results for zirconium alloys and this is applied to cold-worked Zircaloy-2, cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium alloys.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: A method is described for correlating biaxial tubular and uniaxial in-reactor creep results for zirconium alloys and this is applied to cold-worked Zircaloy-2, cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium alloys.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: A method is described for correlating biaxial tubular and uniaxial in-reactor creep results for zirconium alloys and this is applied to cold-worked Zircaloy-2, cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium alloys.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The pressure tubes in most of these reactors are subject to temperatures of 260 to 300°C, internal pressures of about 1 kgf/mm² from the hot heavy-water fuel coolant, and fast-neutron fluxes of up to 3 × 10¹³ n/cm²s (>1 MeV)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: The pressure tubes in most of these reactors are subject to temperatures of 260 to 300°C, internal pressures of about 1 kgf/mm² from the hot heavy-water fuel coolant, and fast-neutron fluxes of up to 3 × 10¹³ n/cm²s (>1 MeV)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Uniaxial tension creep tests [1,2] and diameter measurements on experimental pressure tubes installed in the National Research Universal (NRU) reactor [3] have shown that fast-neutron flux greatly increases creep rates at 260 to 300°C for all the zirconium alloys tested.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: Uniaxial tension creep tests [1,2] and diameter measurements on experimental pressure tubes installed in the National Research Universal (NRU) reactor [3] have shown that fast-neutron flux greatly increases creep rates at 260 to 300°C for all the zirconium alloys tested.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_004_chunk5
evidence_span: These are 20 percent cold-worked Zircaloy-2, 23 percent cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium.

evidence_span: These are 20 percent cold-worked Zircaloy-2, 23 percent cold-worked 2.5Nb zirconium, and heat-treated 2.5Nb zirconium.
